content.description: Sit start on a good horizontal edge. Make two powerful moves up to the lip of the boulder.
Start with both hands in a good jug at about hip height at the far left end of the boulder. Work right along the lip until you meet up with A Page out of Doug's Book, then top out.
content.protection: A few pads. The fall is short, but talus makes it a bit dicey in some spots.

content.description: Just to the left of Thug Butter, there's a small cluster of holds that look decent... until you try to pull off the ground. That in itself is probably V5. From there, you can either fire for the lip out left (and miss) or try to hit the pebble straight above you (and fail). The grade is an estimate.

Start with hands on short, right-facing flake and smooth edge. Hit the seam, then the pinchy bulge, then go up left to the lip.  

  The crux is getting established and making the first move. Flexibility will be helpful here.

Start with both hands on the right-facing flake. Make one big move to the lip, then traverse right a few moves for the comfiest mantel.One of the starting footholds broke shortly after the first ascent. This might make it a bit harder to get established.

climbs.name: A Page Out of Doug's Book

content.description: Do the same start position for Nut Flexor, then move left along the obvious crack system.

Starbag Boulder is a single puddingstone boulder about 50 feet away from the Temple Overhangs. The bottom half is overhanging, and the top half flattens out to a good lip. 

  In Spring 2015, a group of rock gym staff went out to Hammond Pond for some bouldering. One of them remarked that the climbs at the area seem to receive fewer stars than they deserved. "They're not sandbagged," he said, "they're starbagged." About a week later, this boulder was rediscovered, and the name stuck. 

Eds. This boulder has climbed upon long ago.
